attributes.alt: Book cover for My Body. The cover shows a girl holding a drawing that represents the bones of her body. Behind her are drawings of various body parts.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking:
What body parts help us move?
Read for enjoyment and entertainment, noticing vocabulary in context.
Show understanding of text read aloud; Share observations about stories.
Understand and use academic language; Distinguish words that sound similar but have different meanings.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of common objects.
Challenge children to classify pictures as body parts or not body parts.
Guide children to talk about each body part or non-body part.
What are the parts of our bodies?  What do they do?
What body parts can you find in this book?
How can your body stretch to be as tall as you can be? How can you make yourself small?
How can you sort body parts into different groups?
What body part can you draw? What does it look like?
What materials can you use to build a body part?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of the word body?
How can you use blocks to build a tower as high as your arm?

attributes.alt: Book cover for My Body. The cover shows a girl holding a drawing that represents the bones of her body. Behind her are drawings of various body parts.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to find opportunities to talk about the Mind Builder.
Show understanding of text read aloud; Share observations about stories.
Follow classroom rules and routines; Take responsibility for shared materials and jobs.
Show emerging proficiency on tasks requiring eye-hand coordination.
Exercise good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Help children explore different ways to communicate.
Guide children to discover that there are a variety of rules that have to do with communication.
What are the parts of our bodies?  What do they do?
What body parts help you jump?
Show how you can you use your whole body to pretend that you are scared? Happy or silly?
How many fingers do you have on each hand?
Can you write about three ways to take care of your body?
Can you trace your hand? What picture can you make with that outline?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of message? Can you write it?
Can you build something that you find on a playground?

TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. My Body by Andrea Pinnington and Penny Lamprell. Copyright © 2012 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.

attributes.alt: Book cover for My Body. The cover shows a girl holding a drawing that represents the bones of her body. Behind her are drawings of various body parts.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share comprehension skill
book  and asking the guiding lesson:
Show understanding of text read aloud; Share observations about stories.
Share and celebrate written products; Write with some letter-sound correspondence.
Show emerging proficiency on tasks requiring hand-eye coordination.
Help children recall information and vocabulary from the book.
Talk about what makes each part important and encourage conversational turn taking.
What are the parts of our bodies?  What do they do?
Can you name a body part you have more than one of?
Can you show me how you can get around on your legs in different ways?
Can you use connecting cubes  to measure your hand?
Can you write about one thing you learned about your body?
Draw a picture of your foot.
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word down? Can you write it?
Can you build something that could help you sleep?
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. My Body by Andrea Pinnington and Penny Lamprell. Copyright © 2012 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas page for Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes. A boy is posing and words with lines point to parts of his body, including the head, eyes, ears, nose, mouth, shoulders, knees, and toes.
Book cover for My Body. The cover shows a girl holding a drawing that represents the bones of her body. Behind her are drawings of various body parts.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about their bodies and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting texts
Read interactively and connect to this week’s Concept Question:
What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?
Show understanding of text read aloud; Share observations about stories.
Understand and use academic language; Distinguish words that sound similar, but have different meanings.
Share and celebrate written products; Write with some letter-sound correspondence.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of common objects.
Trace the outline of children’s bodies onto drawing paper.
Ask them to color the outline. Have them point to the head, shoulders, knees, and toes
What are the parts of our bodies?  What do they do?
Where do you see shoulders and knees in this book?
How would you move if you used your arms to walk?
Place your hand in the outline of your hand. Which is bigger?
What did you find out about your body that surprised you? What can you write about it?
What could you use to make a play toe or finger?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of toes? Is it the same sound you hear at the beginning of foot?
Build the biggest hat in the world for a giant. Do you think the giant would also have huge shoulders, knees, and toes?
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. My Body by Andrea Pinnington and Penny Lamprell. Copyright © 2012 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.

attributes.alt: Book cover for My Body. The cover shows a girl holding a drawing that represents the bones of her body. Behind her are drawings of various body parts.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to have children act out how they use body parts, sing a song about body parts, and introduce vocabulary
What body parts are under your skin?
Read and retell to keep children engaged and to spur imagination.
Show understanding of text read aloud; Share observations about stories.
Share and celebrate written products; Write with some letter-sound correspondence.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of common objects.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
How do you keep your body parts healthy?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
What are the parts of our bodies?  What do they do?
If you wrote a book about one body part, which would it be?
Can you show me how you would move if you couldn’t bend your legs?
Can you use blocks to measure your feet?
Imagine that you have a body part with super powers. What would you do?
Draw a picture of your brain. Write something that your brain might tell another part of your body.
Imagine the sound you make when you eat tasty food. What letters make that sound?
Use materials to make a picture of your face. What did you use and why?
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. My Body by Andrea Pinnington and Penny Lamprell. Copyright © 2012 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
